text: Quantification of <extra_id_0> vitamin D receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA by competitive polymerase chain reaction in PBMC : lack of correspondence with common allelic variants .

It has been recently claimed that polymorphism for the <extra_id_0> vitamin D receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> VDR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) influences several aspects of calcium and bone metabolism .

To evaluate the physiologic plausibility of these claims , we compared the abundance of the <extra_id_0> VDR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA in peripheral blood mononuclear cells ( PBMCs ) between different <extra_id_0> VDR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> genotypes using a quantitative reverse transcribed polymerase chain reaction-based method .

The method is based on the coamplification of <extra_id_0> VDR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> cDNA and an internal standard consisting of known concentrations of a human <extra_id_0> VDR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> CDNA mutated at a BglII restriction site ; the interassay coefficient of variation is 11 % .

To validate the method , we made use of earlier receptor binding studies indicating that normal human monocytes and activated , but not resting , lymphocytes expressed the <extra_id_0> VDR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

The concentration of the <extra_id_0> VDR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA was 10 ( -8 ) to 10 ( -7 ) g / g of total RNA in cell-sorted monocytes and in in vitro activated lymphocytes , but only 10 ( -12 ) g / g of total mRNA in resting lymphocytes , establishing that the <extra_id_0> VDR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA determined by our method in PBMCs is due to constitutive expression in monocytes .

Following an initial genotype screening of 85 normal volunteers by polymerase chain reaction or restriction fragment length polymorphism analysis , 14 individuals with the Bb genotype , 12 with the bb genotype , and 12 with the BB genotype were selected .

The concentration of the <extra_id_0> VDR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA , corrected for the number of monocytes , was similar among the three genotype groups , as were the other variables examined : serum calcitriol , <extra_id_0> serum osteocalcin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and vertebral and hip bone density .
We conclude that <extra_id_0> VDR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> polymorphism does not affect the abundance of the <extra_id_0> VDR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA .
